snippet: It’s an age-old question: Does success have more to do with talent and effort, or simply good fortune? Sociologists found some answers in an experiment with 48 songs by indie bands.
abstract: Robert H Frank Economic View column looks at the age-old question of whether success has more to do with talent and effort, or is simply good fortune; notes sociologists conducted an experiment with 48 songs by indie bands, showing how feedback can be a vitally important random effect; points out the fate of products in general--but especially of those in the intermediate-quality range--often entails an enormous element of luck.
lead_paragraph: It’s an age-old question: Does success have more to do with talent and effort, or simply good fortune? Sociologists found some answers in an experiment with 48 songs by indie bands.

headline.print_headline: Will the Skillful Win? They Should Be So Lucky
headline.seo: Of Luck and Success — Economic View
headline.main: Luck vs. Skill: Seeking the Secret of Your Success
